Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Topology Optimization for Additively Manufactured Metal Castings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) Program collaborative research award will develop an integrated design-manufacture framework by coupling topology optimization design methods with additive manufacturing processes. Topology optimization is a systematic, computational tool for designing high performance devices and components. Topology-optimized designs, however, are often geometrically complex and thus difficult, if not impossible, to fabricate with traditional manufacturing processes. Additive manufacturing is arising as a potential means for overcoming this obstacle, as its layer-wise fabrication approach enables the creation of geometrically complex components without negatively affecting production cost or throughput. However, despite this natural synergy, additive manufacturing and topology optimization approaches have not yet been integrated into a comprehensive design-manufacture framework. Without this integration, topology-optimized designs may be incompatible with additive manufacturing and require tedious and potentially deleterious post-process alterations to conform to manufacturing restrictions. The primary goal of this research is thus to optimize parts for as-built conditions by (i) identifying, characterizing, and understanding the aspects of an additive manufacturing process that impose constraints on part geometry and (ii) advancing topology optimization methods to incorporate these constraints. Thus the work will substantially improve both the efficiency of the engineering design process and the efficacy of the resultant engineered artifacts. The integrated design-manufacture optimization capability will be of considerable benefit to a broad range of industries, including automotive, agricultural, and aerospace where (for example) the realization of lightweight large-scale components could lead to substantial energy savings. The multidisciplinary research team will also create integrated educational modules and provide research opportunities for underrepresented groups.

As manufacturing constraints are specific to each additive manufacturing process, the research team will focus on designing components to be manufactured via the 3D sand printing process in which metal parts are made by casting molten metal into 3D printed sand molds. The team will identify, characterize, and quantify the aspects of this additive manufacturing and metal casting process chain that impose constraints on component geometry and mathematically incorporate these constraints into the topology optimization method. The topology optimization approach will have roots in projection-based algorithms where manufacturing design variables are coupled to the physical and analysis spaces to naturally achieve manufacturability. Maintaining rigor in the design framework will facilitate extension to other materials and additive manufacturing processes. The team will design, fabricate, and experimentally test an engineered component for a case-study (provided by the industrial partner) to validate the developed design-manufacture framework.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Topology optimization is a computational tool that automates the design of high performance components and products. Topology-optimized designs, however, are often geometrically complex and thus difficult, if not impossible, to fabricate with traditional manufacturing processes. The layer-based fabrication approach of additive manufacturing enables the creation of such complex topologies and thus provides an avenue towards realizing topology optimization-designed structures. Despite this natural synergy, topology optimization and additive manufacturing approaches have not yet been fully integrated into a comprehensive design-manufacture framework.  Johns Hopkins University teamed with Virginia Tech and GOALI partner ExOne to address this gap.  The primary research goals at Johns Hopkins were to create topology optimization design methods and algorithms that integrate the manufacturing constraints within the design process to ensure generated designs can be readily manufactured without manual re-design by an engineer or significant post-processing.  The team focused on 3D sand printing (3DSP) process, where metal is cast into complex sand molds that are created by binder jetting 3D printing.  Towards this goal, Virginia Tech and ExOne provided guidance and characterization data related to the 3DSP process to Johns Hopkins, which then used this data to motivate creation of new design methods and algortihms.  

 

Several new topology optimization algorithms were created through this project.  Chief among these were methods for (a) constraining the minimum size of designed features in multiple directions, (b) constraining the minimum inclination angle of designed features, (c) preventing enclosed pores in designs, and (d) dramatically reducing the computational expense of topology optimization problems on desktop computing.  The ability to control minimum feature size in multiple directions is critical to additive manufacturing, and particularly for 3DSP.  As characterized by VT, the minimum feature size of the structural material must be constrained to ensure parts can be de-powdered before casting and to ensure cast material may flow through the resulting casting channels.  Further, the in-plane feature resolution of binder jetting must be respected, as well as build layer heights as the printing proceeds in a layer-by-layer fashion.  These constraints were addressed through development of a novel projection-based method for topology optimization.  The ability to control the minimum allowable inclination angle of structural features is likewise critical to ensure optimized designs can be manufactured via casting.  This property has corollaries to overhang constraints in other additive manufacturing processes, including direct metal laser melting, stereolithography, and fused deposition modeling.  Fabrication of overhang features requires the use of sacrificial support structures that must be removed mechanically (e.g., machining or grinding) or chemically, depending on the manufacturing process.  The ability to design structures that do not require support structures therefore reduces material consumption and fabrication time, and reduces the number, time and cost of post-processing treatments required to produce additively manufactured parts.  The team successfully developed a mathematically rigorous projection-based approach for implementing channel inclination/overhang constraints in topology optimization, thereby removing the need for sacrificial support structures through design.  The team also created algorithms for preventing the appearance of enclosed pores in topology-optimized designs.  Such pores can not be de-powdered and thus trap sand within the produced part, leading to parasitic mass and structural behavior that is different than predicted by the design process.   The team also created a reduction-based topology optimization method that used static condensation to solve large systems of equations resulting from analysis of the governing physics through a series of mathematically equivalent smaller systems.  This approach allowed very large scale problems with millions of pixels to be solved on a laptop computer.   Finally, the developed algorithms were employed to re-design a structural component for an aerospace and an automotive application, with the objective of reducing mass while meeting structural requirements.  

 

Results of the project were disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed publications and through presentations at scientific conferences, workshops, and seminars, including seminars delivered to industry, academia, and government laboratories.  The team also created hands-on activities for delivery at science fairs of local elementary schools, created new courses and new course content in the area of design for additive manufacturing for undergraduate and graduate students, and provided research opportunities for two PhD students, thus providing a direct impact on future workforce development at multiple levels of education. 

 

In addition to collaboration with automotive, aerospace, and manufacturing companies, the novel overhang constraint approach created through this project has been implemented in commercial software by multiple computer aided design software companies.  This has enabled tremendously broad impact of the project as design engineers from a wide range of industries, including infrastructure, automotive, aerospace, biomedical, and energy use such software to design products.  The ability to design high performance products rapidly that can be directly manufactured, with reduced material usage, fabrication time, and post-processing treatments, ultimately leads to material cost savings, material conservation, and reductions in operating costs and fuel usage in transportation-related applications.  

 


Last Modified: 05/06/2020
Modified by: James K Guest
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Topology optimization is a computational tool that automates the design of high performance components and products. Topology-optimized designs, however, are often geometrically complex and thus difficult, if not impossible, to fabricate with traditional manufacturing processes. The layer-based fabrication approach of additive manufacturing enables the creation of such complex topologies and thus provides an avenue towards realizing topology optimization-designed structures. Despite this natural synergy, topology optimization and additive manufacturing approaches have not yet been fully integrated into a comprehensive design-manufacture framework. Johns Hopkins University teamed with Virginia Tech and GOALI partner ExOne to address this gap. The primary research goals at Johns Hopkins were to create topology optimization design methods and algorithms that integrate the manufacturing constraints within the design process to ensure generated designs can be readily manufactured without manual re-design by an engineer or significant post-processing. The team focused on 3D sand printing (3DSP) process, where metal is cast into complex sand molds that are created by binder jetting 3D printing. Towards this goal, Virginia Tech and ExOne provided guidance and characterization data related to the 3DSP process to Johns Hopkins, which then used this data to motivate creation of new design methods and algortihms. Several new topology optimization algorithms were created through this project. Chief among these were methods for (a) constraining the minimum size of designed features in multiple directions, (b) constraining the minimum inclination angle of designed features, (c) preventing enclosed pores in designs, and (d) dramatically reducing the computational expense of topology optimization problems on desktop computing. The ability to control minimum feature size in multiple directions is critical to additive manufacturing, and particularly for 3DSP. As characterized by VT, the minimum feature size of the structural material must be constrained to ensure parts can be de-powdered before casting and to ensure cast material may flow through the resulting casting channels. Further, the in-plane feature resolution of binder jetting must be respected, as well as build layer heights as the printing proceeds in a layer-by-layer fashion. These constraints were addressed through development of a novel projection-based method for topology optimization. The ability to control the minimum allowable inclination angle of structural features is likewise critical to ensure optimized designs can be manufactured via casting. This property has corollaries to overhang constraints in other additive manufacturing processes, including direct metal laser melting, stereolithography, and fused deposition modeling. Fabrication of overhang features requires the use of sacrificial support structures that must be removed mechanically (e.g., machining or grinding) or chemically, depending on the manufacturing process. The ability to design structures that do not require support structures therefore reduces material consumption and fabrication time, and reduces the number, time and cost of post-processing treatments required to produce additively manufactured parts. The team successfully developed a mathematically rigorous projection-based approach for implementing channel inclination/overhang constraints in topology optimization, thereby removing the need for sacrificial support structures through design. The team also created algorithms for preventing the appearance of enclosed pores in topology-optimized designs. Such pores can not be de-powdered and thus trap sand within the produced part, leading to parasitic mass and structural behavior that is different than predicted by the design process. The team also created a reduction-based topology optimization method that used static condensation to solve large systems of equations resulting from analysis of the governing physics through a series of mathematically equivalent smaller systems. This approach allowed very large scale problems with millions of pixels to be solved on a laptop computer. Finally, the developed algorithms were employed to re-design a structural component for an aerospace and an automotive application, with the objective of reducing mass while meeting structural requirements. Results of the project were disseminated broadly through peer-reviewed publications and through presentations at scientific conferences, workshops, and seminars, including seminars delivered to industry, academia, and government laboratories. The team also created hands-on activities for delivery at science fairs of local elementary schools, created new courses and new course content in the area of design for additive manufacturing for undergraduate and graduate students, and provided research opportunities for two PhD students, thus providing a direct impact on future workforce development at multiple levels of education. In addition to collaboration with automotive, aerospace, and manufacturing companies, the novel overhang constraint approach created through this project has been implemented in commercial software by multiple computer aided design software companies. This has enabled tremendously broad impact of the project as design engineers from a wide range of industries, including infrastructure, automotive, aerospace, biomedical, and energy use such software to design products. The ability to design high performance products rapidly that can be directly manufactured, with reduced material usage, fabrication time, and post-processing treatments, ultimately leads to material cost savings, material conservation, and reductions in operating costs and fuel usage in transportation-related applications.
